properties.name: Beaver Slide Trail
properties.notes:
Beaver Slide Trail https://www.nps.gov/places/beaver-slide-trail.htm

The Hike

This hike is a hidden gem! The Beaver Slide Trail leads hikers past many scenic ponds and swamps. Abundant bald cypress, magnolias, hornbeam, moss, and ferns line this easy walk through the woods.

The hike is a 1.5-mile roundtrip loop with an out-and-back section at the beginning.

Getting Here

GPS Coordinates:
30.573146, -94.642435

The trailhead is on FM 943, a half-mile west of its junction with FM 1276. It’s 3 miles east of Segno and 23 miles east of Livingston. Look for a wooden sign that indicates the trailhead; parking is available on the highway shoulder.

Accessibility

The trail has a slight downhill grade at the start. Its surface is a mixture of dirt and leaves, with some small wooden bridges. Hazards include puddles, muddy sections, and large tree roots.

More Information

  • Located in the Big Sandy Creek Unit of Big Thicket National Preserve
  • Backcountry camping is allowed in spring and summer with a free permit
  • Download a trail map

properties.name: Beech Woods Trail
properties.notes:
Beech Woods Trail https://www.nps.gov/places/beech-woods-trail.htm

The Hike

The Big Thicket forms the southwestern limit of the range of the American beech tree, which extends from southeast Texas to the northeastern United States and Atlantic Canada. Follow the Beech Woods Trail to see magnificent beech trees, along with magnolia and loblolly pine.

The trail is a 1-mile loop with an out-and-back section at the beginning. If you want to hike further, follow the old logging road beyond the loop to explore more of the Beech Creek Unit.

Getting Here

GPS Coordinates:
30.719469, -94.227299

The trailhead is on FM 2992 near Spurger. From Kountze, head north on US 69/287, then east on FM 1013, then north on FM 2992. From Woodville, head east on FM 1746, then south on FM 2992.

Accessibility

The beginning of the trail follows a wide, old dirt road. The trail portion is generally wide-enough for a wheelchair, but some obstacles exist, such as tree roots and uneven surfaces. The trail is hard-packed soil, covered with leaves.

More Information

  • Located in the Beech Creek Unit of Big Thicket National Preserve
  • Backcountry camping is allowed in spring and summer with a free permit
  • Download a trail map

properties.name: Big Sandy Trail
properties.notes:
Big Sandy Trail https://www.nps.gov/places/big-sandy-trail.htm

The Hike

The Big Sandy Trail has more topography than other trails in the preserve, and goes through many different ecosystems. It is the only trail in the preserve that is open to horseback riding and bicycling as well as hiking. Don't be fooled by the name, though, as the Big Sandy Trail is not sandy—it's named for nearby Big Sandy Creek.

The trail is 18 miles roundtrip, out-and-back, with a loop section at the end.

Getting Here

GPS Coordinates:
30.614785, -94.670931

The trailhead is on Sunflower Road, about 3 miles west of FM 1276 near Dallardsville.

Safety

Hunting is allowed in the vicinity of the Big Sandy Trail from October 1 to February 28. Wear orange if you visit this trail during hunting season. The Big Sandy Trail is the only trail in Big Thicket National Preserve that goes through a hunting area.

Accessibility

The Big Sandy Trail follows wide, old dirt roads. Trail users can expect to encounter tree roots, muddy stream crossings, and washboarded sections. While the grade is gentle, there are prolonged uphill and downhill sections.

More Information

  • Located in the Big Sandy Creek Unit of Big Thicket National Preserve
  • Seasonal activities that require a free permit: backcountry camping (spring and summer), hunting (fall and winter)
  • Download a trail map

properties.name: Birdwatchers Trail
properties.notes:
Birdwatchers Trail https://www.nps.gov/places/birdwatchers-trail.htm

The Hike

The Birdwatchers Trail, located at the confluence of Menard Creek and the Trinity River, provides views of the sandbars along the Trinity River. The trail is 1 mile roundtrip, out-and-back.

Getting Here

GPS Coordinates:
30.488474, -94.837047

The trailhead is located about 20 miles northeast of Cleveland, TX, and 3 miles north of Romayor. From FM 787 in Romayor, head north on FM 2610, then turn left onto County Road 2161, then left on Forest Park. Follow Forest Park into the woods until you reach the trailhead.

More Information

  • Located in the Menard Creek Corridor Unit of Big Thicket National Preserve

properties.name: Cattail Marsh
properties.notes:
Cattail Marsh https://www.nps.gov/places/cattail-marsh.htm

Fantastic birding, abundant aquatic wildlife, and miles of hiking paths make this a great place for nature-lovers. Watch for alligators sunning themselves along the banks. A wooden boardwalk extends into the marsh so people can get a closer look at its wildlife.

Tyrrell Park

Cattail Marsh is located inside of Tyrrell Park, managed by the city of Beaumont. Restrooms and picnic facilities are available throughout the park; however, there are no restrooms at Cattail Marsh.

Getting Here

From Interstate 10 in Beaumont, exit at Walden Road and go east, then go straight onto Tyrrell Park Road. The entrance to Tyrrell Park is on Babe Zaharias Drive. Once inside the park, follow the signs to Cattail Marsh as the road loops past the golf course and stables.

Accessibility

The paths around Cattail Marsh are wide, flat, and consist of hard-packed soil and short grasses. The wooden boardwalk is wheelchair-accessible. Use the elevator to reach the top of the observation deck and information center.

properties.name: Centennial Forest
properties.notes:
Centennial Forest https://www.nps.gov/places/centennial-forest.htm

Replanting Longleaf Pines

The “Centennial Forest” is an ongoing project to restore a healthy, thriving longleaf pine savannah habitat to the Big Thicket. Named in honor of the National Park Service's centennial anniversary in 2016, the project has successfully seen over 100,000 longleaf pine seedlings planted by NPS staff, volunteers, students, and partner organizations.

Why replant longleaf pines? This tree species was once one of the most abundant pine species in the southeastern United States; however, it has been reduced to less than three percent of its former range due to logging and fire suppression. A healthy longleaf pine savannah provides habitat for many birds, pollinators, and plants that live nowhere else. Texas trailing phlox, an endangered flower, can only be found in the longleaf pine forests of southeast Texas.

Getting Here

GPS Coordinates:
30.649656, -94.670071

The Centennial Forest is located in the Big Sandy Creek Unit near Dallardsville, Texas. There are several sites within the unit that have been replanted. To visit, use Lily Road (unpaved), off of FM 1276 between Dallardsville and US 190. After about 0.5 miles, where Lily Road makes a sharp left turn, there's a bench and exhibit about the forest.

Read more about longleaf pines and the Big Sandy Creek Unit of Big Thicket National Preserve. Volunteer with us on our next tree planting day!

properties.name: Collier's Ferry Boat Ramp
properties.notes:
Collier's Ferry Boat Ramp https://www.nps.gov/places/colliers-ferry-boat-ramp.htm

Located on the Neches River, Collier’s Ferry was once one of the primary river crossings in this area. It ran from 1831-1950 and is named for John Collier and family, who operated it for 50 years.

This site’s most important use was as a cattle crossing on the Opalousas Trail, Texas’ oldest cattle trail, which served as a route for moving cattle from Texas to New Orleans for over 100 years. A record number of 23,000 cattle swam across the river here in a single day in 1879.

Today Collier’s Ferry is a popular city park, fishing site, and boat ramp. It has picnic tables, a playground, and a 1.8-mile walking trail, plus 4 boat ramps and a large parking lot for boats and trailers. It is also the starting point for the Lake Bayou Paddling Trail, an out-and-back paddling trip that is approximately 7 miles roundtrip.

Getting Here

GPS Coordinates: 30.132568, -94.095898

From US 69/96/287 in Beaumont, head east on Lucas Street, then turn left onto Pine Street. The boat ramp is at the north end of Pine Street, just past the cemetery. Alternatively, from I-10 in Beaumont, exit at Pine Street and head north until you reach the boat ramp.

More Information

  • Paddling in Big Thicket National Preserve
  • Collier's Ferry to Lake Bayou Paddling Trail

properties.name: Confluence Boat Ramp
properties.notes:
Confluence Boat Ramp https://www.nps.gov/places/confluence-boat-ramp.htm

Named for the confluence of the Neches River and Pine Island Bayou, this paved boat ramp provides access to the waterways of the Beaumont Unit.

Getting Here

GPS Coordinates:
30.161472, -94.113581

It's located on the east bank of the Neches River, across from the LNVA Saltwater Barrier. From I-10 in Vidor, head north on FM 105 for 4 miles, then turn left on FM 1131. After 3.6 miles on FM 1131, veer left onto Four Oaks Ranch Road; after about 3.5 miles, the boat ramp will be on your right.

More Information

  • Located in the Beaumont Unit of Big Thicket National Preserve
  • No restrooms

  • Paddling in Big Thicket National Preserve

properties.name: Cooks Lake Day-Use Area
properties.notes:
Cooks Lake Day-Use Area https://www.nps.gov/places/cooks-lake-day-use-area.htm

Cooks Lake Day-Use Area is a good spot to pull up a chair, relax, and watch the boats go by on Pine Island Bayou. Bring your fishing gear and see what's biting.

You'll want to bring your own chairs as there are no picnic tables or facilities at this site.

Getting Here

GPS Coordinates:
30.18847, -94.17770

From US 69/96/287 between Beaumont and Lumberton, exit at Cooks Lake Road and go east for 0.6 miles until you reach the day-use area parking alongside the road.

More Information

  • Located in the Beaumont Unit of Big Thicket National Preserve
  • Not recommended for launching kayaks or canoes due to steep banks
  • No restrooms

properties.name: Edgewater Day-Use Area
properties.notes:
Edgewater Day-Use Area https://www.nps.gov/places/edgewater-day-use-area.htm

This scenic picnic area lies in a quiet neighborhood along the bank of Pine Island Bayou. It offers beautiful views of the bayou and is a popular spot for anglers. An unmaintained trail follows the bank of the bayou for 1/3 mile to another picnic table where the bayou bends south.

Getting Here

GPS Coordinates:
30.177640, -94.171093

Edgewater Day-Use Area is north of Beaumont. To get here, exit the US 69/96/287 freeway at Tram Road and go east until it ends at Sherwood Drive (after the railroad tracks). Turn left to go north on Sherwood and then turn right on Broadoak Street. Follow Broadoak until it becomes Edgewater Drive, then continue on Edgewater until you reach the day-use area.

Accessibility

The restrooms and picnic area are wheelchair-accessible. The trail along the bayou is flat and generally wide enough for a wheelchair, but the width varies. Hazards include tree roots and muddy areas if it has rained recently.

More Information

  • Located in the Beaumont Unit of Big Thicket National Preserve
  • Not recommended for launching kayaks or canoes due to steep banks

properties.name: Four Oaks Day-Use Area
properties.notes:
Four Oaks Day-Use Area https://www.nps.gov/places/four-oaks-day-use-area.htm

The Four Oaks Day-Use Area sits on the east bank of the Neches River. Enjoy a picnic here and fish from the banks of the river.

Getting Here

GPS Coordinates:
30.187913, -94.099697

Four Oaks is located on Four Oaks Ranch Road, off of FM 1131, northwest of Vidor.

More Information

  • Located in the Beaumont Unit of Big Thicket National Preserve
  • Not recommended for launching kayaks or canoes due to steep banks
  • No restrooms

properties.name: Franklin Lake
properties.notes:
Franklin Lake https://www.nps.gov/places/franklin-lake.htm

Franklin Lake is inhabited by a forest of bald cypress trees, many of which are draped with Spanish moss.

The lake lies in the bottomlands near the Neches River. An unpaved boat launch provides access for kayaks, canoes, and small boats.

Getting Here

GPS Coordinates:
30.471820, -94.115880

From Silsbee, head north on FM 92 until you reach Cravens Camp Road, then turn right. Follow Cravens Camp Road until you reach unpaved Franklin Lake Road, then turn left. Franklin Lake lies at the end of the road; look for trees marked with yellow paint. Road signs may be missing or not visible.

More Information

  • Located in the Neches Bottom & Jack Gore Baygall Unit of Big Thicket National Preserve

properties.name: Has Your GPS Misled You?
properties.notes:
Has Your GPS Misled You? https://www.nps.gov/places/gps-sign.htm

If you're taking the Lance Rosier Unit driving tour, your GPS has NOT misled you!

If, on the other hand, you ARE trying to find the visitor center, your GPS may have misled you, though not by ill will. The unusual geography of Big Thicket National Preserve often causes map apps to direct travelers into remote parts of the preserve, which consists of 15 separate sections—called “units”—that are spread out over 7 southeast Texas counties. All of those units are considered an equal part of Big Thicket National Preserve—your map app just doesn't know which one you want to visit!

To get familiar with the layout of the preserve, take a look at the park map, either on the NPS App or the official park brochure, available online and at the visitor center (which, now you know, is not down this road).

properties.name: Kirby Nature Trail
properties.notes:
Kirby Nature Trail https://www.nps.gov/places/kirby-nature-trail.htm

The Hike

Experience the biodiversity of the Big Thicket on the Kirby Nature Trail. This is a great place for first-time visitors and experienced naturalists alike. Life is abundant in this neck of the woods, with grand, old cypress trees, swampy baygalls, dense forest, and the tranquil waters of Village Creek.

The inner loop is 1.5 miles, with an additional (highly-recommended) 0.3-mile loop to see the cypress trees and knees. The outer loop is 2.5 miles and encompasses most of the inner loop's scenery, plus a little extra.

The 17-mile Turkey Creek Trail begins on the north side of the Village Creek Bridge, across from a picnic area on the Kirby outer loop.

Getting Here

GPS Coordinates:
30.462038, -94.350882

The trailhead is on FM 420, about 8 miles north of Kountze. From US 69/287, head east on FM 420 for 2.5 miles. Follow the signs to the parking area. The trail begins next to historic Staley Cabin.

Accessibility

Staley Cabin and the first ¼-mile of the loop (going clockwise) are wheelchair-accessible, with a downhill grade. The path from the parking lot to Staley Cabin is a mixture of pavement and wooden boardwalk. The trail is mostly hard-packed soil and leaves, with several wooden boardwalks. The trail is wide enough for wheelchairs but the surfaces can be uneven with slight dips, tree roots, and washouts.

More Information

  • Located in the Turkey Creek Unit of Big Thicket National Preserve
  • Download a trail map

properties.name: LNVA Saltwater Barrier Boat Ramp
properties.notes:
LNVA Saltwater Barrier Boat Ramp https://www.nps.gov/places/lnva-saltwater-barrier-boat-ramp.htm

Launch your boat here to explore the Neches River and Pine Island Bayou. The 4.8-mile Cooks Lake to Scatterman Paddling Trail begins here.

The saltwater barrier, managed by the Lower Neches Valley Authority, was constructed to keep saltwater from the Gulf of Mexico from mixing with the freshwater from the Neches River.

Getting Here

GPS Coordinates: 30.155200, -94.116000

From US 69/96/287 in Beaumont, head east on Lucas Street, then turn left onto Bigner Road. The boat ramp is at the end of Bigner Road, just past the saltwater barrier.

More Information

  • Located next to the Beaumont Unit of Big Thicket National Preserve
  • Paddling the Big Thicket

properties.name: Lance Rosier Unit Sign
properties.notes:
Lance Rosier Unit Sign https://www.nps.gov/places/lance-rosier-unit-sign.htm

Lance Rosier (1886–1970) was a naturalist who devoted his life to protecting the Big Thicket.

He was born near here in 1886 and later moved to Saratoga. Rosier grew up exploring the thicket and was fascinated with its diverse plant life. Uninterested in hunting for jobs or game animals, Rosier preferred to hunt for rare flowers. He would wander through the woods, sometimes for days, making observations of the plant and animal life he saw.

Known as “Mr. Big Thicket,” Rosier was self-taught but knew just about every plant he encountered in the Big Thicket. He led popular guided tours for visiting professors, politicians, researchers, students, and just about anyone who wanted to learn about the thicket. His expertise contributed to greater awareness of the Big Thicket's biodiversity, and its need for protection.

Rosier was an advocate for the creation of a Big Thicket park. He worked with grassroots organizations, including the Big Thicket Association, to push the state and national governments to protect the woods that he so dearly loved.

Lance Rosier continued to guide people into the thicket until his death in 1970. His dream was finally realized when Big Thicket National Preserve was established on October 11, 1974. Though he did not live long enough to see his beloved Big Thicket become a park, his legacy lives on in the Lance Rosier Unit.

properties.name: McQueens Landing Boat Launch
properties.notes:
McQueens Landing Boat Launch https://www.nps.gov/places/mcqueens-landing-boat-launch.htm

McQueens Landing is the northernmost boat launch on the Big Thicket section of the Neches River.

This boat launch is a good place to start a multi-day float trip. From here, it's 51 river miles south to the next reliable boat ramp on the Neches River, the Evadale boat ramp on US 96.

Getting Here

GPS Coordinates:
30.791401, -94.150862

To get to McQueens Landing, take US 190 east from Woodville, or west from Jasper, until you reach FM 777. Go south on FM 777 until you reach a fork with County Road 150. Go south on County Road 150. Pass through a few unmarked intersections, but keep going straight through them. County Road 150 turns right and left through a small residential area then ends at the boat launch.

properties.name: Neches River - Evadale Boat Ramp
properties.notes:
Neches River - Evadale Boat Ramp https://www.nps.gov/places/neches-river-evadale-boat-ramp.htm

As with many historical communities along waterways, Evadale began as a ferry crossing across the Neches River.

It was known as Richardson’s Bluff in the 1830s, then Ford’s Bluff after it was purchased by the Ford brothers in 1849. It served as a collection point for logs, which were floated down the Neches River to sawmills in Beaumont. Timberman John Henry Kirby later purchased the land and named it after Miss Eva Dale, a teacher at Southeast Texas Male and Female College in Jasper. Today the boat ramp is used primarily by anglers.

Getting Here

GPS Coordinates:
30.356259, -94.094502

The ramp is located on US 96, just west of Evadale, on the west bank of the Neches River. Northbound and southbound lanes on US 96 have off-ramps for the boat ramp.

More Information

  • Paddling in Big Thicket National Preserve

properties.name: Oilfield Cemetery
properties.notes:
Oilfield Cemetery https://www.nps.gov/places/oilfield-cemetery.htm

The Oilfield Cemetery dates back to 1888 for the burial of Joseph S. Cotten, son of John Fletcher Cotten—one of the area's first European American settlers.

In the early 1900s, when the oil boom struck Saratoga, many oil derricks and structures were built throughout the oilfield, surrounding the cemetery. Residents decided to move the town away from the oilfield, but continued to bury their dead “down in the oilfield.”

Today, the Oilfield Cemetery is still in use, and the people of Saratoga continue to bury their loved ones there. A large cedar tree stands majestically in the middle of cemetery while the sounds of active oil pumpjacks infiltrate the stillness.

Private Property

Note: The cemetery is privately-owned but open to the public; please be respectful of the graves. The oilfield surrounding the cemetery is private property.

properties.name: Pine Island Bayou - US 69/96/287 Boat Ramp
properties.notes:
Pine Island Bayou - US 69/96/287 Boat Ramp https://www.nps.gov/places/pine-island-bayou-us-69-96-287-boat-ramp.htm

This paved boat ramp along US Highway 69/96/287 provides access to Pine Island Bayou. A small pier next to the ramp goes down to the water.

Getting Here

GPS Coordinates:
30.17949, -94.18673

The boat ramp is located between Lumberton and Beaumont, on the north bank of Pine Island Bayou. Access the ramp from the southbound lane of US 69/96/287 and Eastex Freeway.

More Information

  • Paddling in Big Thicket National Preserve

properties.name: Pitcher Plant Trail
properties.notes:
Pitcher Plant Trail https://www.nps.gov/places/pitcher-plant-trail.htm

The Hike

The Pitcher Plant Trail leads hikers to a vast, natural garden of carnivorous pitcher plants and sundews.

The trail is a 1-mile loop with options to hike further north or south on the Turkey Creek Trail. To see the pitcher plants, follow the paved path from the trailhead as it leads to a wooden boardwalk over the pitcher plant bog. Past the boardwalk, the trail becomes a dirt path as it goes through the woods, briefly joins the Turkey Creek Trail, and loops back to the trailhead.

Green metal blazes mark the Pitcher Plant Trail and red metal blazes mark the Turkey Creek Trail.

Getting Here

GPS Coordinates:
30.582384, -94.336575

The trailhead is on County Road 4850, about 2 miles south of FM 1943 and 4.5 miles east of Warren.

Accessibility

The beginning of the trail is paved and leads to a wooden boardwalk through the pitcher plant bog. Beyond the boardwalk, the trail is a dirt path, which can get muddy following heavy rain.

More Information

  • Located in the Turkey Creek Unit of Big Thicket National Preserve
  • Backcountry camping is allowed along the Turkey Creek Trail year-round with a free permit
  • Download a trail map

properties.name: Roy E. Larsen Sandyland Sanctuary
properties.notes:
Roy E. Larsen Sandyland Sanctuary https://www.nps.gov/places/roy-e-larsen-sandyland-sanctuary.htm

Managed by The Nature Conservancy, this 5,654-acre property protects a number of diverse plant communities, from cypress sloughs and bottomland hardwoods along Village Creek to upland longleaf pine forests dotted with prickly pear cactus.

Hikers can explore over 6 miles of trails. Prescribed burns help to keep the forest open, making it an excellent place to see birds and wildflowers. An overlook on a bluff just a short walk in provides a view looking down at Village Creek.

Address: 4208 Hwy 327 West, Silsbee, TX 77656
Hours: Dawn to dusk daily

  • No restrooms
  • Day-use only; no camping allowed
  • No pets

properties.name: Saratoga Oilfield
properties.notes:
Saratoga Oilfield https://www.nps.gov/places/saratoga-oilfield.htm

Oil production in Saratoga began in the late 1800s and continues to this day.

In 1860, John Fletcher Cotten discovered an oil seep nearby—his hogs had been wallowing in it—and constructed a primitive oil well on the site. However, his well did not produce very much, and he abandoned it shortly thereafter. 

In the years that followed, Saratoga drew interest from exploratory oil prospectors, known as “wildcatters,” and a small producing oil well was built on-site. 

In the early 1900s, the oilfield became commercially successful for the first time as oil production soared. Many large wooden derricks were built and construction began on a railroad to connect the town's oil and lumber industries with larger markets. The rapid growth from the oil boom slowed by the end of the decade, though wells in the 1950s and 1970s remained profitable.

Production continues today with many small pumpjacks in action around the oilfield.

Private Property

Note: The Saratoga Oilfield is on private property and trespassing is not allowed. You may drive through the oilfield on Rosier Park Road, which is public.

properties.name: Staley Cabin
properties.notes:
Staley Cabin https://www.nps.gov/places/staley-cabin.htm

Built in 1934, Staley Cabin is a good example of a log cabin used by homesteaders in the 19th and 20th centuries.

Thinking that this site was available for homesteading, Jimmy Staley built the three-room cabin for his wife and four children using pine timber cut from the property. The original chimney was made of mud and the roof had cypress shingles. Outside, Jimmy’s wife, Elda, planted acorns that became the large oaks that loom over the cabin today. Next to the cabin, the Staleys had a vegetable garden surrounded by a hog-proof fence and an orchard of plum and fig trees.

After living here for a couple of years, Jimmy Staley found out that his homestead was built on timber company land! The Kirby Lumber Company owned the property and tried to evict the family but eventually decided to let them remain after Jimmy signed an acknowledgement of tenancy.

In 1962, Jimmy Staley sold the cabin. Later owners made improvements, including replacements of the roof and chimney. In 1977, three years after the establishment of Big Thicket National Preserve, the National Park Service bought the cabin and surrounding property. The cabin was used as the preserve’s visitor center until 2001.

The inside of the cabin is not open but visitors may walk around the grounds and use the picnic tables. The Kirby Nature Trail starts next to the information kiosk.

More Information

  • Located in the Turkey Creek Unit of Big Thicket National Preserve

properties.name: Sundew Trail
properties.notes:
Sundew Trail https://www.nps.gov/places/sundew-trail.htm

The Hike

This is one of the best places in the Big Thicket to see birds and wildflowers, as well as the tiny red sundew plants.

Both the inner 0.3-mile loop and the outer 1-mile loop pass through a small bog of pitcher plants. The inner loop continues through a savannah that has abundant summer wildflowers, while the outer loop winds through a pine forest with many longleaf pines.

Picnic Area & Pavilion

The picnic area at the trailhead has a large shaded pavilion with 4 picnic tables and 2 charcoal grills.

Getting Here

GPS Coordinates:
30.548274, -94.409666

The trailhead is located about 4 miles south of Warren and 14 miles north of Kountze. From US 69/287, head west on FM 2827, then turn left (south) onto County Road 1910. Follow the signs to the Sundew Trail parking area.

Accessibility

The wheelchair-accessible inner loop has a mix of pavement and wooden boardwalks. The outer loop is a dirt path and can get muddy after heavy rain.

More Information

  • Located in the Hickory Creek Savannah Unit of Big Thicket National Preserve
  • Download a trail map

properties.name: Teel Cemetery
properties.notes:
Teel Cemetery https://www.nps.gov/places/teel-cemetery.htm

The small and secluded Teel Cemetery, first used in 1893, is hidden in the woods of the Big Thicket.

Richard and Nancy Teel were the second European American family to settle in the Saratoga area, after the Cottens. Richard was born in Alabama and moved to Texas with his parents at the age of 18. In 1858, when he was 24, he married Nancy Hart, 16, and the young couple settled in the Big Thicket.

The Teels lived in a log cabin, just west of what is now the cemetery, where they raised a sizable family of 11 children. Nearby, they had an orchard and grew crops including cotton, corn, oats, and sugarcane.

One of their sons, D. J., was the first to be buried here, in 1893. Both Richard and Nancy are buried in this cemetery, along with many of their children and descendants.

The home site remained in the Teel family until 1978, when it was transferred to the National Park Service for inclusion in Big Thicket National Preserve. Sadly, the cabin burned in the 1970s.

Private Property

Note: Though the surrounding land is public land, Teel Cemetery remains privately-owned and is not open to the public. You can read about the history of the cemetery on the Texas Historical Commission sign near its entrance.

Roads in the Lance Rosier Unit are unpaved and often muddy after it rains. Once you're on Rosier Park Road, signage may be missing or not visible. Hunting is allowed in the Lance Rosier Unit from October 1 to February 28; wear orange if you plan to explore the nearby woods during hunting season.

properties.name: Teel Road Cypress Swamp
properties.notes:
Teel Road Cypress Swamp https://www.nps.gov/places/teel-road-cypress-swamp.htm

Still water, towering trees, and a chorus of birds, insects, and frogs invite you to explore the cypress swamp.

Most of the big trees growing out of the water are bald cypress, a conifer native to the southeastern United States. Bald cypress is easily identified by its wide, buttressed trunk, needle-like leaves, and unusual root features called cypress knees.

Cypress knees are whimsical in appearance, looking like a gathering of goblins. They are an above-ground extension of bald cypress roots, though scientists do not fully understand their purpose. Some studies suggest that the knees provide stability in the swampy conditions or help the roots with gas exchange.

Visit during different seasons to see the swamp’s many moods. Spring and summer provide a spectacular amount of greenery. Fall brings a dramatic palette of color as bald cypress leaves turn a rich copper color. Winter’s mood is muted, as the trees’ bare branches are exposed in the chilly air.

Though the swamp is quite scenic, it’s not entirely natural. An abandoned logging road on the west edge of the swamp acts as a dam, holding water in place that would normally flow down to Little Pine Island Bayou. As a result, it created the perfect conditions for a bald cypress swamp.

Explore the Swamp

Feeling adventurous? Explore the swamp on foot. You can choose your own route through or around the swamp—there are no trails here.

  • Don’t get lost. Be mindful of your route through the swamp so you can return to your car.
  • Watch out for snakes.
  • Hunting is allowed here from October 1 to February 28. Wear orange if you enter the woods during hunting season.

properties.name: Turkey Creek Trail - FM 1943
properties.notes:
Turkey Creek Trail - FM 1943 https://www.nps.gov/places/turkey-creek-trail-fm-1943.htm

The Hike

This is the northernmost trailhead for the Turkey Creek Trail. Start here and head south to experience the backcountry of the Turkey Creek Unit.

The entire Turkey Creek Trail is 17 miles long, from FM 1943 to FM 420. Shorter hikes are possible along the route, as the Turkey Creek Trail crosses a few roads and trails along the way.

Getting Here

GPS Coordinates:
30.613469, -94.344245

This trailhead is located 3.5 miles east of Warren on FM 1943.

The Turkey Creek Trail can be accessed via these trailheads as well: Pitcher Plant Trail, County Road 4825, Gore Store Road, and Kirby Nature Trail.

Accessibility

The trail surface is hard-packed soil with uneven surfaces, tree roots, and muddy sections.

More Information

  • Located in the Turkey Creek Unit of Big Thicket National Preserve
  • Backcountry camping is allowed on the Turkey Creek Trail year-round with a free permit
  • Download a trail map

properties.name: Turkey Creek Trail - North of Gore Store Road
properties.notes:
Turkey Creek Trail - North of Gore Store Road https://www.nps.gov/places/turkey-creek-trail-north-of-gore-store-road.htm

The Hike

Catch the Turkey Creek Trail here and head north into the heart of the Turkey Creek Unit.

From this trailhead, it is 9 miles to the northern terminus of the trail at FM 1943. The entire Turkey Creek Trail is 17 miles long, from FM 1943 to FM 420.

Getting Here

GPS Coordinates:
30.522098, -94.346870

This trailhead is on Gore Store Road, about 4 miles east of US 69/287, and about 10 miles north of Kountze. The trailhead will be on the left (north) side of Gore Store Road.

The Turkey Creek Trail can be accessed via these trailheads as well: FM 1943, Pitcher Plant Trail, County Road 4825, Gore Store Road (Southbound), and Kirby Nature Trail.

Accessibility

The trail surface is hard-packed soil with uneven surfaces, tree roots, and muddy sections. Parts of the trail often flood after heavy rain.

More Information

  • Located in the Turkey Creek Unit of Big Thicket National Preserve
  • Backcountry camping is allowed on the Turkey Creek Trail year-round with a free permit
  • Download a trail map

properties.name: Turkey Creek Trail - South of Gore Store Road
properties.notes:
Turkey Creek Trail - South of Gore Store Road https://www.nps.gov/places/turkey-creek-trail-south-of-gore-store-road.htm

The Hike

For a 9-mile roundtrip hike, take the Turkey Creek Trail to the Sandhill Loop. Along the way, you'll encounter cypress sloughs, slope forest, and a sandy, open part of the woods.

The entire Turkey Creek Trail is 17 miles long, from FM 1943 to FM 420.

Getting Here

GPS Coordinates:
30.521094, -94.343759

This trailhead is on Gore Store Road, about 4 miles east of US 69/287, and about 10 miles north of Kountze. The trailhead will be on the right (south) side of Gore Store Road, just past the northbound trailhead.

You can reach the Turkey Creek Trail at these trailheads as well: FM 1943, Pitcher Plant Trail, County Road 4825, Gore Store Road (Northbound), and Kirby Nature Trail.

Accessibility

The trail surface is hard-packed soil with uneven surfaces, tree roots, and muddy sections. A few wooden bridges cross small drainages. Parts of the trail often flood after heavy rain.

More Information

  • Located in the Turkey Creek Unit of Big Thicket National Preserve
  • Backcountry camping is allowed on the Turkey Creek Trail year-round with a free permit
  • Download a trail map

properties.name: Village Creek - Baby Galvez Road Boat Launch
properties.notes:
Village Creek - Baby Galvez Road Boat Launch https://www.nps.gov/places/village-creek-baby-galvez-road-boat-launch.htm

Baby Galvez was once the site of a resort named after the city of Galveston. People came here to swim, picnic, and dance in a pavilion on a hill overlooking the creek. There were even bathhouses for changing into swimsuits.

Today, Baby Galvez is best known for its paved boat ramp providing access to Village Creek. This launch is one of several on the Village Creek Paddling Trail. From here, it is just over 7 miles downstream to the next boat ramp, near Lumberton on US 96.

Getting Here

GPS Coordinates:
30.33450, -94.20391

From 5th Street (BUS-96) in Silsbee, go west on Lindsey Road, then turn left on Baby Galvez Road. The boat ramp is at the end of Baby Galvez Road.

More Information

  • Paddling in Big Thicket National Preserve
  • Village Creek Paddling Trail

properties.name: Village Creek - FM 418 Boat Launch
properties.notes:
Village Creek - FM 418 Boat Launch https://www.nps.gov/places/village-creek-fm-418-boat-launch.htm

This unpaved boat launch between the towns of Kountze and Silsbee lies at the north end of the Village Creek Paddling Trail. From this point it is 8.6 miles downstream to the next boat launch at Texas Highway 327, a stretch that many paddlers describe as the prettiest part of Village Creek.

Getting Here

GPS Coordinates:
30.397794, -94.265024

The ramp is located on Farm-to-Market Road 418 (FM 418) between Kountze and Silsbee. Look for the ramp on the south side of the bridge, on the west bank of Village Creek. A popular sandbar and beach is located on the north side of the bridge.

More Information

  • Paddling in Big Thicket National Preserve
  • Village Creek Paddling Trail

properties.name: Village Creek - TX 327 Boat Launch
properties.notes:
Village Creek - TX 327 Boat Launch https://www.nps.gov/places/village-creek-tx-327-boat-launch.htm

This unpaved boat launch on Texas Highway 327 provides access to the most popular stretches of the Village Creek Paddling Trail. Many canoeists and kayakers launch here to paddle 2.1 miles downstream to the next boat launch at Baby Galvez Road in Silsbee.

Getting Here

GPS Coordinates:
30.346944, -94.239385

The launch is located on TX Hwy. 327 between Kountze and Silsbee. Find the launch on the south side of the bridge, on the west bank of Village Creek.

More Information

  • Paddling in Big Thicket National Preserve
  • Village Creek Paddling Trail

properties.name: Village Creek - US 96 Boat Launch
properties.notes:
Village Creek - US 96 Boat Launch https://www.nps.gov/places/village-creek-us-96-boat-launch.htm

This popular, paved boat ramp just north of Lumberton is managed by Hardin County. From this point it is 3.2 miles downstream to the next boat launch, at Village Creek State Park (check with the state park for the status of their boat launch, as it may be affected by flooding).

Getting Here

GPS Coordinates:
30.28570, -94.19145

Find the boat launch on US 96 about 2 miles north of Lumberton. Northbound and southbound lanes on US 96 have off-ramps for the boat launch.

More Information

  • Paddling in Big Thicket National Preserve
  • Village Creek Paddling Trail

properties.name: Woodlands Trail
properties.notes:
Woodlands Trail https://www.nps.gov/places/woodlands-trail.htm

The Hike

Hike the Woodlands Trail to see Collins Pond, Big Sandy Creek, and dense stands of hardwood trees. Short hills add a few ups and downs to this shaded hike.

The outermost loop is 5.4 miles. Two connector trails create shorter loops of 3.3 or 4.5 miles.

Getting Here

GPS Coordinates:
30.679596, -94.699489

The trailhead is east of Livingston on FM 1276, between US 190 and Dallardsville.

Accessibility

The dirt trail goes through hilly terrain with uneven surfaces. The trail surface consists of leaf-covered hard-packed soil, wooden bridges, and grasses. The section near Big Sandy Creek is often muddy.

More Information

  • Located in the Big Sandy Creek Unit of Big Thicket National Preserve
  • Backcountry camping is allowed on the Woodlands Trail year-round with a free permit
  • Download a trail map

properties.name: “Bridge to Nowhere”
properties.notes:
“Bridge to Nowhere” https://www.nps.gov/places/bridge-to-nowhere.htm

This abandoned bridge, unofficially called the “Bridge to Nowhere” by locals, spans Little Pine Island Bayou. While vehicles can’t cross the bridge anymore, you can still walk across it.

It is not known when the bridge was built, but it likely carried loggers and oil workers across the bayou. After timber and oil production slowed, companies moved on to the next profitable piece of land, leaving behind empty bridges and roads.

Little Pine Island Bayou flows slowly beneath the bridge. On its journey to the Gulf of Mexico, this water will flow into Pine Island Bayou near Bevil Oaks. Pine Island Bayou then flows into the Neches River north of Beaumont. Finally, the Neches pours into Sabine Lake near Port Arthur, where the Sabine River carries it out to the Gulf of Mexico.

Along the bayou, dwarf palmettos add a jungle-like quality to the scenery. One of a handful of palmettos native to Texas, this variety is very tolerant of shade and freezing temperatures.

Walk the Old Road

Feeling adventurous? You can cross the Bridge to Nowhere on foot and follow the old road through the palmettos. The path ends after ½ mile at a pipeline right-of way.

  • Uneven pavement—Watch your step on the Bridge to Nowhere.
  • Watch out for snakes.
  • Hunting is allowed here from October 1 to February 28. Wear orange if you enter the woods during hunting season.
